I take your general point that simpler tests are better. 
But I've seen lot=
s of complex tests and admit that I am not 
always strong enough myself to =
keep them simple. 

The art of writing good unit tests develops over time. =
If you
already consistently write very small, well-named, tightly
focused u=
nit tests and never have to look at any test code
that is written to a less=
er standard, maybe you will never want to
look at an assertion log. But whi=
le you are developing that
skill, an assertion log might be useful.

> If y=
ou aren't going to think about the failure message when you write  
> it, t=
hen don't write one.

It is often the case that you do not realize how unin=
formative
a message is until you see it in action. On a larger scale this
i=
s why people have to write many drafts. If the first time
you see a message=
 is 10 months after your wrote the assertion,
chances are it won't be as in=
formative as if you'd happened
to read it at least once before you committe=
d it.

As for why anyone would write to the console when writing a
test cas=
e, I don't know, but I have often seen it and in
fact have often seen the s=
ystem out being used where an
assert should have been used. This generally =
occurs when
people are first being introduced to unit testing, probably
bec=
ause they have prior experience writing the "I'll just eyeball it"
kind of =
"test". Maybe if by writing an assertion
(generally the same amount of code=
) they could have got something
written to the console as a side effect, th=
ey would write assertions
instead and the net result would be a better test=
 case.

> > 1) eliminating redundant logging statemen=

ng what they expected.

> > 2) improving assertion messages - =
it's often the case that the
> >
> > first time you see the message for an =

> > assertion fails, which may not happen until =
you run a regression test

ou see the message

t realize that the

ul. Better

he

 when you write

> > 3) see finer-grain test r=
esults. Every assertion is a mini-test on its
> > own, but JUnit these mini=
-tests are invisible until they fail.

> Absolutely not. Assertions are =
not mini-tests. A test is a test. If  
> you have multiple unrelated assert=
ions in a test, then move them into  
> their own tests. This leads to a nu=
mber of benefits (more accurate  
> test count metrics, more information wh=
en a test fails, easier to  
> isolate the cause of a failure).
> > 4) by m=
aking logging easy, it can help to avoid the
> > using-system-outs-instead-=
of-asserts syndrome, where new junit test
> > writers will write "test case=
s" that actually just write a bunch of

st writer then eyeballs for expected

> Why would anyone use=
 JUnit to spit things out to the console? If they

ertions that I have
